newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Deal reached on EU part-time work.
newsitem.headline: Deal reached on EU part-time work.

text.p: European Union labour and employers groups reached agreement on Wednesday on rules to guarantee rights to part-time workers.
UNICE, the EU employer's federation, said in a statement that it had completed negotiations on the new rules with ETUC, the trades union group, and CEEP, the public employers group.

The three groups agreed last June to open talks on rights for part-time workers after the European Commission asked them to consider ways of ensuring that employees in a broad range of flexible jobs did not face discrimination.
The Maastricht Treaty's social protocol gives these groups -- the so-called social partners -- the right to strike a deal and then ask the EU Council of Ministers to turn it into EU law.
At UNICE's insistence, the negotiations have been confined solely to part-time work and have not covered other types of flexible jobs such as fixed-term or temporary contracts.
The statement gave no details of the agreement, which will be formally adopted on June 6.
It said the rules were designed to remove discrimination against part-time work and facilitate its development.
